docblock.description: Class that creates forms based on fields passed in.
A class for generating forms based on the models.
Holds the fields on this form.
Assuming out model has two field name and age;
docblock.long-description:
$initial =[
                        'name'=>'mat',
                        'age'=>10
                        ];

                        new Form($initial);

tag.name: param
tag.description: the data displayed on form fields when the form is first loaded.

docblock.description: Gets a single field instance in the form fields array and returns it
docblock.long-description:
Usage

if a form has a fields username, you get the field object: 
$form->get_field('username);

docblock.description: Creates an opening form tag with a base URL built from your config preferences.
docblock.long-description:
It will optionally let you add form attributes and hidden input fields, and will always add the accept-charset attribute based on the charset value in your config file. 
assuming we are using the controller `user/signup` to server this form.
                        echo $form->open(); // goes back to the controller method that served this form.
                        


                        echo form->open('email/send'); // goes to the base_url plus the “email/send” URI segments
This method also detects if the form contains any upload fields a generate a multipart form if they are found. it is also responsible for displaying the form help_text.

Adding Attributes

Attributes can be added by passing an associative array to the second parameter, like this: 
$attributes = array('class' => 'email', 'id' => 'myform');
                        echo form->open('email/send', $attributes);
Alternatively, you can specify the second parameter as a string: 
echo form->open('email/send', 'class="email" id="myform"');
The above examples would create a form similar to this: 
< form method="post" accept-charset="utf-8"
                        action="http://example.com/index.php/email/send" class="email" id="myform" >

docblock.description: Create the form closing tags and displays any errors that have not been display explicitly.
docblock.long-description:
echo form_close($string);
Would produce: 
 </form >

docblock.description: Return the HTML widget (input, radio, textarea e.t.c) for the specified field.
Returns the form label
Creates a form fieldset.
Closes a form fieldset
Returns errors related to the form as a whole.
This method does all the heavy lifting and returns the form object to use.
docblock.long-description:
- Prepares the form fields for use. - Loads the initial data onto the form fields. - It load the necessary libraries needed by this form. 
$form =
                        $form_builder->form();

tag.name: fluent
tag.description: This method is part of a fluent interface and will return the same instance

docblock.description: This method is responsible for setting the initial data to be used on the form.
docblock.long-description:
NB this method only set, form() method is resposible for loading this initial data. This method beyond the normal php data types also accepts a - Queryset- this will be evaluated to get the value. - Any object, as long as its a model object and the model extends the PModel, as long as its primary key is set. as a value for the field 

                        $user = $this->user_model->get(['username'=>'ken']);
                        $form_builder->initial(['username'=>$user', 'password'=>'#$RAdad']);

docblock.description: This is the help information that relates to the whole form and not a specific to a field on the form.
docblock.long-description:
[http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/powerorm.form.Field.html#method_help_text](http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/powerorm.form.Field.html#method_help_text) 
$form_builder->help_text(['Please ensure the email and phone number
                        are valid we
                        will use them for activation of you're account']);

tag.name: param
tag.description: the help information to be displayed with form

docblock.description: This method runs the validation of the form. and return true on success or false on fail.
Class responsible for representing the reverse direction of a relationship.
Creates a reverse connection for a relationship.
This is the model to create a relationship with.
When an object referenced by a ForeignKey is deleted, Powerorm by default emulates the behavior of the SQL constraint ON DELETE CASCADE and also deletes the object containing the ForeignKey.
Used for forms with choices, this set the default option to show
Used to set the field on the model to use for display e.g for the model user_model.
docblock.long-description:
you could set the form_display_field to username, this will result in form select box shown below 
<select >
                        < option value=1 > math // <----- the username.
                        </select >

docblock.description: Works on dropdown, select, radio, checkbox.
docblock.long-description: Used to set the model field to use for the value of the form option fields e.g for the model user_model. you could set the form_value_field to email, this will result in form select box shown below By default the primary key is used.

docblock.description: If True, powerorm will store empty values as NULL in the database. Default is False.
If True, this field must be unique throughout the table.
docblock.long-description:
This is enforced at the database level and by model validation.
If you try to save a model with a duplicate value in a unique field,
This option is valid on all field types except ManyToManyField, OneToOneField, and FileField.
Note that when unique is True, you don’t need to specify db_index, because unique implies the creation of an index.

docblock.description: If True, this field is the primary key for the model.
docblock.long-description:
If you don’t specify primary_key=True for any field in your model, Poweroem will automatically add an AutoField to hold the primary key,
so you don’t need to set primary_key=True on any of your fields unless you want to override the default primary-key behavior.
primary_key=True implies null=False and unique=True. Only one primary key is allowed on an object.
The primary key field is read-only. If you change the value of the primary key on an existing object and then save it, a new object will be created alongside the old one.

docblock.description: The default value for the field.
If True, this field will be indexed.
If True, the field is allowed to be blank on form. Default is False.
docblock.long-description:
Note that this is different than null. null is purely database-related,
whereas form_blank is validation-related.
If a field has form_blank=True, form validation will allow entry of an empty value.
If a field has form_blank=False, the field will be required.

docblock.description: An array consisting of items to use as choices for this field.
docblock.long-description:
If this is given, the default form widget will be a select box with these choices instead of the standard text field.
The first element in each array is the actual value to be set on the model, and the second element is the human-readable name.
For example: $gender_choices = [ 'm'=>'Male', 'f'=>'Female', ]
$gender = ORM::CharField(['max_length'=2, 'choices'=$gender_choices])

docblock.description: Set the html form type to use for this form.
Extra “help” text to be displayed with the form widget.
docblock.long-description:
It’s useful for documentation even if your field isn’t used on a form. Note that this value is not HTML-escaped in automatically-generated forms. This lets you include HTML in help_text if you so desire. For example: 
help_text="Please use the following format: YYYY-MM-DD."

FileField has one optional argument: - upload_to this is the path relative to the application base_url where the files will be uploaded.

docblock.description: The path relative to the application base_url where the files will be uploaded
The maximum length (in characters) of the field.
If True, powerorm will store empty values as NULL in the database. Default is False.
If True, this field must be unique throughout the table.
docblock.long-description:
This is enforced at the database level and by model validation.
If you try to save a model with a duplicate value in a unique field,
This option is valid on all field types except ManyToManyField, OneToOneField, and FileField.
Note that when unique is True, you don’t need to specify db_index, because unique implies the creation of an index.

docblock.description: If True, this field is the primary key for the model.
docblock.long-description:
If you don’t specify primary_key=True for any field in your model, Poweroem will automatically add an AutoField to hold the primary key,
so you don’t need to set primary_key=True on any of your fields unless you want to override the default primary-key behavior.
primary_key=True implies null=False and unique=True. Only one primary key is allowed on an object.
The primary key field is read-only. If you change the value of the primary key on an existing object and then save it, a new object will be created alongside the old one.

docblock.description: The default value for the field.
If True, this field will be indexed.
If True, the field is allowed to be blank on form. Default is False.
docblock.long-description:
Note that this is different than null. null is purely database-related,
whereas form_blank is validation-related.
If a field has form_blank=True, form validation will allow entry of an empty value.
If a field has form_blank=False, the field will be required.

docblock.description: An array consisting of items to use as choices for this field.
docblock.long-description:
If this is given, the default form widget will be a select box with these choices instead of the standard text field.
The first element in each array is the actual value to be set on the model, and the second element is the human-readable name.
For example: $gender_choices = [ 'm'=>'Male', 'f'=>'Female', ]
$gender = ORM::CharField(['max_length'=2, 'choices'=$gender_choices])

docblock.description: Set the html form type to use for this form.
Used for forms with choices, this set the default option to show
Extra “help” text to be displayed with the form widget.
docblock.long-description:
It’s useful for documentation even if your field isn’t used on a form. Note that this value is not HTML-escaped in automatically-generated forms. This lets you include HTML in help_text if you so desire. For example: 
help_text="Please use the following format: YYYY-MM-DD."

A fixed-precision decimal number. SQl column DECIMAL(M,D)
docblock.long-description:
Has two required arguments:
- max_digits
The maximum number of digits allowed in the number. Note that this number must be greater than or equal to decimal_places.
- decimal_places
The number of decimal places to store with the number.
For example, to store numbers up to 999 with a resolution of 2 decimal places, you’d use:
ORM::DecimalField(max_digits=5, decimal_places=2)
And to store numbers up to approximately one billion with a resolution of 10 decimal places:
ORM::DecimalField(max_digits=19, decimal_places=10)
The default form widget for this field is a 'text'.

docblock.description: The maximum number of digits allowed in the number.
docblock.long-description: Note that this number must be greater than or equal to decimal_places.

docblock.long-description:

whereas form_blank is validation-related.

docblock.description: Creates an opening form tag with a base URL built from your config preferences.
docblock.long-description:
It will optionally let you add form attributes and hidden input fields, and will always add the accept-charset attribute based on the charset value in your config file. 
assuming we are using the controller `user/signup` to server this form.
                        echo $form->open(); // goes back to the controller method that served this form.
                        


                        echo form->open('email/send'); // goes to the base_url plus the “email/send” URI segments
This method also detects if the form contains any upload fields a generate a multipart form if they are found. it is also responsible for displaying the form help_text.

Adding Attributes

Attributes can be added by passing an associative array to the second parameter, like this: 
$attributes = array('class' => 'email', 'id' => 'myform');
                        echo form->open('email/send', $attributes);
Alternatively, you can specify the second parameter as a string: 
echo form->open('email/send', 'class="email" id="myform"');
The above examples would create a form similar to this: 
< form method="post" accept-charset="utf-8"
                        action="http://example.com/index.php/email/send" class="email" id="myform" >

docblock.description: Orm Loader
class that Loads the ORM LIBRARY and all the necessary classes.
docblock.long-description:
Its actually Meant to get around CodeIgniter not using namespaces To start using the orm, load it like any other CODIGNTER library, preferably using autoload 
$autoload['libraries'] = array(
                    'powerdispatch/signal',
                    'powerorm/orm', <------------------------------------ the orm
                    'powerauth/auth'
                    );

PModel

The ORM Model that adds power to CI Model. This class provides the CI MODEL with power by doing two important things : - Use model to determine how the database table it represent looks like - Assigns Model fields Allows creating fields on the model, which represent columns in the database. - Provides easy interaction with the database. This class provides a Queryset object for each class that extends it. The Queryset class Acts like a proxy between the database and the current model. USAGE:

Extending

Extend this class on model classes e.g. 
User_model extends PModel{
                    protected $table_name= '';
                    ...
                    }
The `table_name` variable is optional, this tells the orm which database table this model represents. if not set Table name is taken as model name e.g. user_model above the table would be `user_model`

Interacting with the database

Load model like any other codeigniter model 
$this->load->model('user_model')
Extending the PModel, provides several methods that can be used to interact with the database, e.g. the get() method more on this later. 
$this->user_model->get(['name'=>'john'])
This will return object of the user_model.

How it works

- The first Queryset method invoked on the model creates that models Queryset. Each of this methods below create a new Queryset instance. 
$this->user_model->get(array('name'=>'john'));
                    $this->user_model->all());
- Several Queryset methods can be chained together to refine the query. 
$this->user_model->all()->filter(array('username'=>'admin'));
                    **************************************************
                    SELECT `user`.*
                    FROM `user`
                    *************************************************
                    $this->user_model->all()->filter(array('username'=>'admin'));
                    ----------
                    SELECT `user`.*
                    FROM `user`
                    WHERE `user`.`username` = 'admin'
- Queryset is evaluated to get data from the database. The PModel has more methods read more here [http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/PModel.html](http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/PModel.html)

Queryset

Class for doing database lookups, The look up is done Lazily i.e. Lazy Loading. This class provides several methods for interacting with the database with one important thing to note is that some. Most Methods return a Queryset object and not the database results. This allows for further refinement of the Queryset.

Methods that don't return a Querset.

The following are the methods don't return a Queryset: - \Queryset::get() - \Queryset::size() - \Queryset::delete() - \Queryset::value() - \Queryset::save() - \Queryset::add() Read more of this methods here [http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/powerorm.queries.Queryset.html](http://eddmash.github.io/powerorm/docs/classes/powerorm.queries.Queryset.html)

Creating A Queryset

Each model that extends the `PModel` class automatically gets assigned a Queryset object, using this Queryset you are able perform database lookups. Assuming we have a model class User_model that represents all users in the user database table. We can interact with it as follows: To get one user with the `name=john` 
$this->User_model->get(array('name'=>'john'))
To get All user in the database 
$this->User_model->all()

Refining the Queryset (Method Chaining)

e.g count all users 
 $this->user_model->all()->size(array('name'=>'john'))
get all users with the name `name=john` 
 $this->user_model->all()->filter(array('name'=>'john'))

                    // which can also be handle as follows

                    $this->user_model->filter(array('name'=>'john'))

Getting Results (Lazily Loading and Evaluation)

To get results from the database, the Queryset object has to be evaluated, the reason for this is to hold off from hitting the database until its absolutely necessary, that is when the results are actually needed. A Queryset Evaluation takes place in the following situations :. - When looping through the Queryset using foreach. 
 $admins = $this->role->all();
                    foreach($admins as $admin){
                    ...
                    }
- When using a Queryset like a string e.g. in an echo statement. 
echo $this->role->get(array('name'=>'admin'));
- When testing or existence of a property e.g. using isset(). 
$admin_role = $this->role->get(array('name'=>'admin'));
                    if(isset($admin_role->description)){
                    ...
                    }
. - When the \Queryset::value() method of the Queryset is invoked. 
$admin_role = $this->role->all()->value();
.

See methods for more explanations and usage examples

Some common issues when using ORMs to avoid

-

N+1 Problem

This problem occurs when the code needs to load the children of a parent-child relationship (the “many” in the “one-to-many”). Most ORMs have lazy-loading enabled by default, so queries are issued for the parent record, and then one query for EACH child record. As you can expect, doing N+1 queries instead of a single query will flood your database with queries, which is something we can and should avoid. Consider a simple blog application which has many articles published by different authors. i.e many to one We want to list articles along with their title and author’s name. This could be achieved using the following 
$articles = $this->article_model->all()

                    foreach($articles as $article){
                    $article->author->name;
                    }
Assuming we have 20 articles in the database, the above code will produce 20+1 queries to the database 
 // one to fetch all the articles

                    select * from articles;

                    // then based on the value of foreign_key to the author on each article, an author is
                    // fetched resultin in 20 more queries hence the N+1.

                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' = ?
                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' = ?
                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' = ?
                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' = ?
                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' = ?
To solve this problem use the \Queryset::with(). The method tells the orm to eagerly load the article and authors in one go when the Queryset is being evaluated. which will result in two sql queries as shown below: 
$articles = $this->with(['author'])->article_model->all()

                    foreach($articles as $article){
                    $article->author->name;
                    }

                    // one to fetch all the articles

                    SELECT 'articles'.* FROM 'articles'


                    //one to fetch all authors

                    SELECT 'authors'.* FROM 'authors' WHERE 'authors'.'id' IN (1,2,3,4,5)
example borrowed from [http://www.sitepoint.com/silver-bullet-n1-problem/](http://www.sitepoint.com/silver-bullet-n1-problem/) To avoid this issues using this orm, use the \Queryset::with() method.

docblock.description: The Orm Model that adds power to the CI Model
The ORM Model that adds power to CI Model.
Creates or Updates an object in the database,
docblock.long-description:
How it differentiates between update and create

This methods does an update if the model contains a value on its primary key value else it creates. On create or update this method will return the created object.

Signal Emitted

If the [https://github.com/eddmash/powerdispatch](https://github.com/eddmash/powerdispatch) is enabled, this method emits two signals - powerorm.model.pre_save allowing any receivers listening for that signal to take some customized action. - powerorm.model.post_save allowing any receivers listening for that signal to take some customized action.

USAGE

To create an new object 
$role = new role();
                        $role->name = "ceo";
                        $role = $role->save();
To update existing an new object e.g. assuming the above object got a primary key of `3` we can update its name as follows 
 $role = $this->role->get(3);
                        $role->name = "chief executive officer";
                        $role = $cat->save();

docblock.description: Eager loading, this will solve the N+1 ISSUE
docblock.long-description:
USAGE:

To Eager load related items of a single item This method takes all the fields that need to be eagerly loaded. 
$category = $this->category_model->with(["products"])->get(array("id"=>1));

                        $category->products; // the products are now accessible like so

                        foreach($rr->products as $product){
                        echo $product->name;
                        }
To Eager Many To Many Relationship 
$roles = $this->role->with(['permissions'])->filter(array('user_model::id'=>1));
                        foreach ($roles as $role) {
                        echo $role ;

                        foreach ($role->permissions as $perm) {
                        echo $perm->name;
                        }
                        }
To Eager Load more than one relationship , this eager loads a user roles and products.

docblock.description: If True, powerorm will store empty values as NULL in the database. Default is False.
If True, this field must be unique throughout the table.
docblock.long-description:
This is enforced at the database level and by model validation.
If you try to save a model with a duplicate value in a unique field,
This option is valid on all field types except ManyToManyField, OneToOneField, and FileField.
Note that when unique is True, you don’t need to specify db_index, because unique implies the creation of an index.

docblock.description: If True, this field is the primary key for the model.
docblock.long-description:
If you don’t specify primary_key=True for any field in your model, Poweroem will automatically add an AutoField to hold the primary key,
so you don’t need to set primary_key=True on any of your fields unless you want to override the default primary-key behavior.
primary_key=True implies null=False and unique=True. Only one primary key is allowed on an object.
The primary key field is read-only. If you change the value of the primary key on an existing object and then save it, a new object will be created alongside the old one.

docblock.description: The default value for the field.
If True, this field will be indexed.
If True, the field is allowed to be blank on form. Default is False.
docblock.long-description:
Note that this is different than null. null is purely database-related,
whereas form_blank is validation-related.
If a field has form_blank=True, form validation will allow entry of an empty value.
If a field has form_blank=False, the field will be required.

docblock.description: An array consisting of items to use as choices for this field.
docblock.long-description:
If this is given, the default form widget will be a select box with these choices instead of the standard text field.
The first element in each array is the actual value to be set on the model, and the second element is the human-readable name.
For example: $gender_choices = [ 'm'=>'Male', 'f'=>'Female', ]
$gender = ORM::CharField(['max_length'=2, 'choices'=$gender_choices])

docblock.description: Creates or Updates an object in the database,
docblock.long-description:
How it differentiates between update and create

This methods does an update if the model contains a value on its primary key value else it creates. On create or update this method will return the created object.

Signal Emitted

If the [https://github.com/eddmash/powerdispatch](https://github.com/eddmash/powerdispatch) is enabled, this method emits two signals - powerorm.model.pre_save allowing any receivers listening for that signal to take some customized action. - powerorm.model.post_save allowing any receivers listening for that signal to take some customized action.

USAGE

To create an new object 
$role = new role();
                        $role->name = "ceo";
                        $role = $role->save();
To update existing an new object e.g. assuming the above object got a primary key of `3` we can update its name as follows 
 $role = $this->role->get(3);
                        $role->name = "chief executive officer";
                        $role = $cat->save();

docblock.description: Eager loading, this will solve the N+1 ISSUE
docblock.long-description:
USAGE:

To Eager load related items of a single item This method takes all the fields that need to be eagerly loaded. 
$category = $this->category_model->with(["products"])->get(array("id"=>1));

                        $category->products; // the products are now accessible like so

                        foreach($rr->products as $product){
                        echo $product->name;
                        }
To Eager Many To Many Relationship 
$roles = $this->role->with(['permissions'])->filter(array('user_model::id'=>1));
                        foreach ($roles as $role) {
                        echo $role ;

                        foreach ($role->permissions as $perm) {
                        echo $perm->name;
                        }
                        }
To Eager Load more than one relationship , this eager loads a user roles and products. 
$usr= $this->user_model->with(["products", "roles"])->get(["id"=>1]);

docblock.description: ORM QuerySet implementation.
Class for doing database lookups, The look up is done Lazily i.e. Lazy Loading.
docblock.long-description: This class provides several methods for interacting with the database with one important thing to note is that some methods return a Queryset object while other return the expected result object.

docblock.description: Fetches exactly one record from the database table by matching the given lookup parameters.
docblock.long-description: This method Returns a Queryset for further refinement USAGE:. To fetch a single row in the database with the name john. $this->User_model->get(array('name'=>'john')) To fetch a single row in the database with the `name=john` and `age=20`. $this->User_model->get(array('name'=>'john', 'age'=20)) To fetch a single row in the database with the primary key 1, where primary key column is `id`. $this->User_model->get(1) if primary key is not `id` you can pass the primary key field $this->User_model->get(array('pk'=>1))

tag.name: param
tag.description: an array of field and the value to look for, or an integer-primary key.

tag.name: see
tag.description: To fetch more than one item based on some conditions.

docblock.description: Works like the get method but difference is it can return more than one item.and return a Queryset
docblock.long-description:
Implements the where part of a query and returns rows limited by the where clause.

USAGE:

Normal Filtering

To fetch all rows in the database with the name `john`. 
$this->User_model->filter(array('name'=>'john'))
To fetch all rows in the database with the `name=john` and `age=20`. 
$this->User_model->filter(array('name'=>'john', 'age'=20))

Related Filter

To fetch all rows based on there related data e.g fetch user model where role is `admin`. 

                        $roles = $this->user_model->filter(array("role::name"=>"admin"));

Be More Specific

You can be more specifics on your conditions by using the lookup options available to you. $this->user_model->filter('username__contains'=>'eri'); this will run the following sql `select * from user_table where username like %eri%`
